So as someone who didn't watch a lot of the lions as a kid growing up, and only sees Barry on highlight films, honest question:
I know he was one of the best ever, but did he get tackled for loss a loss a lot? i know he had huge plays all the time, and he broke tackles like no other, but it seems like his playing style (ei: often reversing field behind the line of scrimmage) would get punished alot too, I mean when they work, they're amazing (thus highlight reels) but when he'd get stopped seems like it'd be for pretty big losses... I guess i'm asking if he's kinda like Brett Farve (in his prime), amazing when hes good, while at the risk of losing big yards when hes not.

basic run down:
-What you'll need 3 blocks that are the same size, -registration sheet -paper
step 1) carve black block step 2) make registration sheet for black block, and print step 3) remove black block and replace with new blank block, re-register previously printed block onto the new block, (make sure registration is tight) and run thru the press -the wet print will offset onto the blank block, step 4) repeat with another block, step 5) carve out color blocks step 6) print color block, let dry, print 2nd color block, let dry, print black block, and your done

WRITING.TITLE: BeginIng of a List of contemporary printmakers

So someone asked be about who they should know in the modern print world, so I started making a list (which is in no way complete) figured y'all might like to see what I have so far, and feel free to comment with anyone you think should be added to this list

Cannonball Press http://www.cannonballpress.com/
Aaron S Coleman http://aaroncolemanprintmaking.com

Bill fick http://billfick.com/
Carlos Hernandez http://www.carloshernandezprints.com/
Aliene de Howell http://www.alienedesouzahowell.com/
Tom Huck http://www.evilprints.com/
Ron Liberti http://www.ron-liberti.com/
Little Friends of Printmaking http://thelittlefriendsofprintmaking.com/
Joseph Lupo http://josephlupo.com/
Dan Macadam http://www.crosshairchicago.com/
Mazatl http://justseeds.org/artists/mazatl/
Barry McGee
Dennis Mcnett http://wolfbat.com/
Kathryn Polk http://www.nonindigenouswoman.com/ Minna Resnick http://www.minnaresnick.com/
Artemio Rodriguez http://artemiorodriguez.net/
Favianna Rodrigeuz http://www.favianna.com
Jay Ryan http://thebirdmachine.com/
Jenny Schmidt http://www.bikinipressinternational.com/
Sean Starwars http://www.seanstarwars.com/
Robert Swainston http://www.robswainston.com/
Swoon http://shop.swooninprint.com/
Kevin Tong http://tragicsunshine.com/
Tugboat Print Shop http://www.tugboatprintshop.com/
Ericka Walker http://www.erickawalker.com/

Herd to tell entirely what's going on, but it looks like your ink might be too think (which would slow drying) so my first suggestion would be to tone that down.
Something else you could do is to throw some (just a schmidge) cobalt drier into your ink with will quicken your drying times (it's toxic so wear gloves)
also I've found the thinner the fabric the quicker it dries, when I printed on muslin it dried basically overnight, when I printed on a Tshirt it took like 3-4 weeks to dry (dunno why the disparity, but haven't investigated it too much.

The only problem I had at first was getting the thumbnail to show up right, because it's always the first picture you upload, even if you change the order later on. Also if the image size is to big it might not show a thumbnail.... And if you don't have a thumbnail the odds of your post getting traction go down.
Also it's not that artist websites are particularly difficult to navigate, it's just they are each different, often take SLIGHTLY longer to load/navigate, which In the internet age can mean the difference between hitting the back button or spending a minute looking at your work. I've had a picture ripped off imgur and rehosted before, but whatever, if people want to steal your stuff their going to do it, just like music/software, pirates gonna pirate.

Honestly in my opinion, I like links to imgur. That's mostly because they're often easier to navigate, straight to the point and no bullshit. Also I'm mostly a mobile user so it's easier for me to flick thru your pics on imgur rather than hope that your site is easy to go thru on an iPhone. Do I really care about self promotion, due to website vs imgur... Nah it's all an ease of use kinda thing. if I like what you show, and I want to see more then I'll put up with navigating your site.

So there's been a lot of people saying they don't know anyone, they don't know how to meet people, well tonight from 6-10 at the breadbox (behind west Sixth Brewery) there will be a bunch of art people out... "But I'm awkward..." Art people are awkward too, so come out an meet people. If you want an ice breaker just look at a piece, then look at the person next to you and say something like "we don't you think this is rather representative of neo classical braoque, with influences by DeGalvario? It really captures to feel of his work, btw I'm _______" BOOM you have a friend! Or they'll call your bullshit, but it's a 50/50 shot
Also since it's right by the brewery, you can head there after, do dinner at smithtown or County Club, so many possibilities

"9-1-1, what's your emergency?"
"Police-man, there's a dog at this bar and it offends me"
"Ok.... Is it causing problems?"
"Well it's adorably watching a game of billards, but it could step in broken glass any second, did I mention I was offended by it's presence?"
"Ummm.... Ok is the owner of the establishment asking the dog to leave?"
"No, the owner is just playing catch with the dog, it's disgusting. Have you dispatched SWAT yet? This is seriously offensive"
"Yah.... So this line is actually for emergencies.... You just sound like an asshole who doesn't like dogs so I'm going to recommend you just.... Idk... Leave"
"BUT IM OFFENDED"

And yah they want to tear it down, and use the space, instead of paying taxes on a "worthless" lot, wouldn't you do the same thing?
it'd be like if you had a broken down POS el camino in your driveway, and wanted to get rid of it so you could park your car you actually drive there. But your neighbors demand you save the el camino, and put in far more money into it than the car is even worth. And in the end you have an el camino, that has to much money spent on it, and your still parking your new car in the road.

To my understanding it's basically like an machine kinda like a xerox printer, but the image is printed kind of like a silkscreen, where the matrix is wrapped around a cylinder (kinda like how they print money, putting engraved plates on a drum, but instead here they have a rounded silkscreen-esque drum that you have ink in the center of and push ink thru). so it prints with the speed if a xerox but has the feel/look of a silkscreen.

When discussing art there are no absolutes everyone is different everyone on the form vs content will be at a different point. Imagine it as a line between 1 and 100. Form being 1 and content being 100 (the number doesn't matter it's just to serve as an illustration). A few people will be absolute 1's and 100's but 99.9999% of the people fall somewhere in between. None are correct none are wrong it's just whatever works for you.

Personally I think this is a great question, and one that's extremely hard to answer simply.
One of the hardest things an artist can do (IMO) is create a unique style. It's hard, it takes a long time and much trial and error. Although some artist you look at May have styles that seem very simple and minimal, they've often taken years upon years to refine. It's not something you can just ok my style will be "X" and it'll be good. It's more of a seeing where your work takes you and embracing/ pushing that. Until little over half way thru undergrad I stuggled to find "my style" most of my work took on the form of the assignments I was assigned, and looked like "student work" it was fairly boring and generic. I always envied those around me that had their thing, their style, their nuances. I wondered why I hadnt found mine, would I ever find mind? I think I found my "style" one semester then I was taking a semester break from art school, when I stopped having to make assignments, where I stopped making work for my teachers, and made a piece that was for me, and only me, no one else would need to see it, just me. That was MY point where my style started to define itself, when I started to do what I wanted and didn't care what anyone else said. When I embraced what I liked, and made that I like. Granted that point had been slowly building for 5+ years, and has slowly evolved since then. Looking back at my "student work" I could see threads of what lead to my style, I saw how my work was a progression that lead me where I wanted to get to. So I think all I'm really trying to say is keep pushing, keep working, keep looking for those threads, and eventually you'll find yourself. GL

Oh Geeze your doing 100 days, GL it gets hard after awhile. I did one print a day for 6 months and it was a bitch staying with it. I ended up making each month themed, otherwise I started running outa things to carve.
Also try to work on getting your prints cleaner, those smudges need to go. Wash you hands if they get inky. When I'm printing I try to pick up my plates with my ring finger and pinky, the use your other 3 fingers to pick up your paper. That way it minimized the chance of ink getting on your prints.

If your just talking about multi block printing, don't really have a demo... I'll make one next time, but it's really pretty simple, though describing it takes a minute.
1) Get 2 blocks (or more) that are same size. 2) carve your key block (the black one in my case). 3) make a registration sheet just like you would for any other relief print. 4) ink up, register, and print your key block. 5) take out your key block and replace it with the 2nd blank block. 6) put the inked up print back onto of the new block ( making sure the registration is the same) 7) run it back thru the press. 8) you now have the key block transferred exactly onto your 2nd block. Carve it up, print it, then print your key block on top of that, just make sure your registration is the same every time and you'll be multi block printing in no time
This is me printing with one yesterday to kinda give you the jist http://instagram.com/p/1OWWgEjowW/
printed it on a Vandercook, which makes registration super easy.

WRITING.TITLE: I made a relief print of my idiot dog

WRITING.TEXT: IMO Feel like as far as progression goes 2011-2012 was pretty decent, then it kinda plateaued after that, sure art history reference was nice but as far as technically ability goes not much changed from 12-15
That water rendering is on point man.

So I might get butchered for this but, Honestly the carving/drawing is the main part I actually care about. Although sometimes it's nice, I the actual printing process is one of my least favourite parts, and is more of a chore that's part of getting to my end goal, the prints. if I could, I'd have assistants do all my printing for me, but I don't, So using a vandercook to speed the process that I don't like, and let me get back to the part I enjoy more.... I'm all for it.
It's sooooooooo fast, used to working on an etching press, and unless I'm making bigger work, don't know if I'd want to go back.
Figured it's for a printmaking show, would feel wrong if the posters weren't hand printed.

WRITING.TITLE: Linoleum Relief Poster Hand-printed on a Vandercook

WRITING.TEXT: Point D was just about the closing statement in the article. I'm done on this thread, but I like it when 2 opposing views can have a decent discourse on reddit, without telling the other to "suck a bag of dicks" so even though I disagree with you, I'll say cheers, and have my upvote.

I'm not going to argue the validity of the mural but a couple points... A) the last thing we need is more horse/ bourbon art. B) the building is privately owned and the mural was privately funded, its more akin your nieghbor having an "monstrosity" of a house which annoys you rather than them vandelizing your fence. C) Its not like the nursery was in the middle of a sublime pasture encased in rolling hills, its in the middle of a dilapidated industrial district flanked by train tracks and abandoned warehouses. (honestly i feel like the nursery is more out of place than the mural is, but thats just an opinion) D) "art should stay in a museum" what you fail to realize is that meuseum art is highly curated/ often highly pretencious/ and thus often highly institutionalized (ei only what the meuseum wants to be "art" is "art") which creates a huge barrier for any artist who isn't dead. Graffiti gives an artist a canvas which can still reach an audience without having to edit himself to fit within the bounties which are acceptable by institutional standards.
